item.title: Snowden, in Russia, Seeks Asylum in Ecuador
item.description: Edward J. Snowden was believed to have stayed the night inside the transit zone of a Moscow airport after fleeing from Hong Kong, possibly en route to Ecuador or another nation where he could seek asylum.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and PETER BAKER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Sunday, a crowd of journalists greeted a passenger on the same Hong Kong flight Edward J. Snowden took to Moscow.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: J.W. Anderson and the Addictive Rush of Fashion
item.description: Suzy Menkes, the IHT’s fashion editor, talks to Jonathan (“J.W. Anderson”) Anderson at London Fashion Week about unisex styling, working with Donnatella Versace and the “addictive” rush of the industry today.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 24
item.description: Edward J. Snowden arrives in Moscow; arrests in Spanish doping ring; tourists killed in Himalayas; Scottish schools downplay testing; men’s wear on the Milan runways; cycling superhighways in Copenhagen; Monaco’s soccer-player buying spree.
item.dc:creator: By INTERNATIONAL
item.media:description: The Hong Kong government announced on Sunday that it had allowed the departure from its territory of Edward J. Snowden.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Poll Finds Australians Uneasy About Chinese Investment
item.description: A new poll by Australia’s Lowy Institute found that many Australians remained concerned about Chinese investment because of perceptions of poor transparency in Chinese companies and a lack of democracy and rule of law in China.
item.dc:creator: By SUE-LIN WONG
item.media:description: Miners working for the Australian company Rio Tinto watch an on-site blast. The Australian company was an investment target of a Chinese company but the deal, which drew opposition in Australia, did not go through.

item.title: India Ink: India-U.S. Relations: The Search for a Transformative Moment
item.description: India and the United States need to build upon the success of the civil nuclear deal and work toward the next defining moment.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN KHURSHID
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, wearing a white cap, walking with U.S. President Harry S. Truman at the National Airport in Washington, on Oct. 11, 1949.

item.title: Soldiers Clash With Sunni Sheik’s Followers in Southern Lebanon
item.description: Clashes in Sidon pitted the Lebanese Army against the followers of Sheik Ahmad al-Assir, a Sunni Muslim who called for the disarming of Hezbollah.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and HANIA MOURTADA

item.title: Offering Snowden Aid, WikiLeaks Gets Back in the Game
item.description: WikiLeaks assisted Edward J. Snowden in his escape from Hong Kong and is providing legal assistance, placing the organization back in the global spotlight.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, left, at Ecuador’s embassy in London.

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on Snowden’s Asylum Pursuit
item.description: The Lede is providing live updates on the former National Security Agency contractor who has acknowledged disclosing information about American surveillance programs.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ and JENNIFER PRESTON
item.media:description: The Hong Kong government announced on Sunday that it had allowed the departure from its territory of Edward J. Snowden.

item.title: China Said to Have Made Call to Let Leaker Depart
item.description: Analysts said the Chinese government allowed Edward J. Snowden to leave Hong Kong to prevent a long legal battle with the United States and to maintain diplomatic ties.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Supporters of Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, with his photograph at a demonstration outside the American Consulate in Hong Kong this month.

item.title: Taliban Flag Is Gone in Qatar, but Talks Remain in Doubt
item.description: Afghan officials confirmed that the Taliban had removed an objectionable sign and a flag on display at their office in Doha, but whether Afghanistan will send its official delegation remains questionable.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Snowden, in Russia, Seeks Asylum in Ecuador
item.description: Edward J. Snowden arrived in Moscow on Sunday as American officials pressed Russia to turn him over and warned countries in Latin America not to harbor him or allow him passage.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Sunday, a crowd of journalists greeted a passenger on the same Hong Kong flight Edward J. Snowden took to Moscow.

item.title: Brazil, Fortune and Fate Turn on Billionaire
item.description: Once worth $34.5 billion, Eike Batista’s holdings are now estimated at $4.8 billion and falling. With Brazil’s streets churning in protest, the markets — and Mr. Batista’s fortune — are on uncertain terrain.
item.category: Embraer - Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica SA|ERJ|NYSE
item.dc:creator: By PETER LATTMAN and SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: A floating oil production and storage unit belonging to the shipbuilder OSX, part of Mr. Batista’s group of industrial holdings.

item.title: Memo From Turkey: Mosque Dream Seen at Heart of Turkey Protests
item.description: The building of a mosque is an old dream for Turkey’s Islamists, and played a role in the last military intervention in Turkish politics in 1997.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: Official Corruption in Mexico, Once Rarely Exposed, Is Starting to Come to Light
item.description: Several former governors and public officials have recently found themselves under investigation or facing public scorn.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY
item.media:description: Tapes of Andrés Granier, center, the former governor of Tabasco State, boasting of his lifestyle were leaked to a radio station.

item.title: Kerry Prods India to Cut Greenhouse Gas Emissions
item.description: On his first visit to India as secretary of state, John Kerry urged the nation to take action against global warming.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and JOHN M. BRODER
item.media:description: John Kerry on his first visit to India as the secretary of state.

item.title: Bank of Israel Chief in ’90s Is Choice to Lead It Again
item.description: Jacob Frenkel, an inflation hawk who was Bank of Israel governor in the 1990s, will replace Stanley Fischer, who is stepping down at the end of June.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Abbas Accepts Prime Minister’s Resignation
item.description: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority asked Prime Minister Rami Hamdallah to stay on until a replacement could be found.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Chinese Dissident Arrives in Taiwan
item.description: The activist Chen Guangcheng, who fled to the United States last year, is expected to further anger Chinese officials with his 18-day visit to Taiwan, where he will address the legislature.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Egyptian General Warns Against Violence as Anniversary Approaches
item.description: The defense minister said the military would act decisively to prevent violence during protests against President Morsi next week.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: Mandela’s Condition Is Reported to Deteriorate to ‘Critical’
item.description: News of the former South African leader’s downturn used the strongest language yet after three weeks of hospitalization.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Militants Kill 10 Climbers in Himalayas of Pakistan
item.description: In one of the most brazen attacks on foreigners in the country in recent years, militants killed 10 tourists and their Pakistani guide.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Ambulances carry the bodies of 10 tourists and a Pakistani guide who were attacked on Nanga Parbat.

item.title: 6 Are Killed by Worker in Shanghai
item.description: A Shanghai man is accused of beating one person to death and shooting five others after a dispute, a rare instance of gun violence in China.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Spanish Police Arrest 84 in Crackdown on Doping
item.description: Spain’s Interior Ministry said the police dismantled two criminal gangs involved in importing and distributing steroids, blood boosters and growth hormones.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Weather Hampers Rescue of Flood Victims in India
item.description: Dense fog slowed efforts to evacuate thousands of people stranded in the northern India state of Uttarakhand, where at least 1,000 people have died.
item.dc:creator: By BASHARAT PEER
item.media:description: A pilgrim carrying a child was transported across a flooded river by rescuers in the northern India state of Uttarakhand.

item.title: Letter From Washington: 2 Alternatives for Obama's Summer
item.description: It isn't unusual to establish a framework for success or failure of U.S. presidencies by the end of the first summer of the second term.
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW
